choices.B: Cross-object formulas can reference fields from master-detail or lookup relationships.
choices.E: Cross-object formulas can be referenced in roll-up summary fields.
choices.C: Cross-object formulas can reference child fields to perform an average.
choices.A: Cross-object formulas can reference fields from objects that are up to 10 relationships away.
choices.D: Cross-object formulas can expose data the user does not have access to in a record.

comments.content: Based on that link, answer is A, B, D

discussion.content:
A. Cross-object formulas can reference fields from objects that are up to 10 relationships away.
B. Cross-object formulas can reference fields from master-detail or lookup relationships.
D. Cross-object formulas can expose data the user does not have access to in a record.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true regarding cross-object formulas? (Choose three.)
Which two statements are true about Apex code executed in Anonymous Blocks? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
Unlike classes and triggers, anonymous blocks execute as the current user and can fail to compile if the code violates the user's object- and field-level permissions.

comments.content: Based on that link, answer is B, E

discussion.content: B AND E ARE CORRECT ACCORDING TO APEX DOCUMENTATION
C and E is the correct option

comments.content: No. You don't have system level access in annon apex.

choices.E: Successful DML operations are automatically committed.
choices.D: All DML operations are automatically rolled back.
choices.C: The code runs in system mode having access to all objects and fields.
choices.A: The code runs with the permissions of the user specified in the runAs() statement.
choices.B: The code runs with the permissions of the logged in user.

comments.content: A is used to run tests, not check coverage.

discussion.content: A AND D are correct in the setup go to test execution
I just checked and you can calculate code coverage on the apex classes in setup so C and D are correct

Selected Answer: CD
Why A isn't the correct answer: The following message is display in the ApexTest Execution page: To see the current code coverage for an individual class or your organization, go to the Apex Classes page.

A. The Apex Test Execution page: The Apex Test Execution page in the Salesforce Setup menu can be used to run all tests in a sandbox and view overall code coverage for the org.

D. The Tests tab of the Developer Console: The Developer Console is a tool within Salesforce that developers can use to write and test Apex code, as well as to monitor debug logs and code coverage. Developers can use the Tests tab in the Developer Console to view code coverage for all Apex classes and triggers in a sandbox.

Selected Answer: CD
C and D

comments.content: I meant Setup - Apex Classes * (option c)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
In Setup - Apex tests - there is an option to "estimate your organization's code coverage"

choices.B: The Test Suite Run panel of the Developer Console
choices.D: The Tests tab of the Developer Console
